Hundreds of protesters marched along Chicago's Michigan Avenue yesterday to call for justice days after the release of a video showing police officer Jason Van Dyke, who is white, shooting 17-year-old Laquan McDonald, who was black, 16 times.
The shooting took place in October of 2014.
And while the city gave a $5 million settlement to the McDonald family, the video was not released until this week and only by court order.
Officer Van Dyke continued to work at a desk job until he was charged this week.
We turn now to Carol Marin, political editor at NBC 5 and WTTW TV in Chicago and a columnist at the Sun-Times.
Carol, thanks so much for being with us.

With me today is civil rights icon Reverend Joseph Lowery, who cofounded the Southern Christian Leadership Conference and was a confidant of the Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. We are also joined by Afi-Odelia Scruggs, an independent journalist and writer.
Thank you both for coming on.
Thank you.
Reverend JOSEPH E.
LOWERY (Cofounder, Southern Christian Leadership Conference): My pleasure.
Reverend Lowery, first off.
Tell us how you felt the night that Obama clinched the number of delegates needed to secure the Democratic nomination and gave his speech.
Well, when I got up off the floor...
(Soundbite of laughter)
I braced myself off.
Oh, frankly, it was a warm and very spiritual feeling.
In the Old Testament, and you know you've got a preacher here, so you may have some biblical references, which I hope doesn't bother anything on public radio.
You go right ahead.
But the Old Testament talks about, the year of jubilee has come.
I think this is a jubilee experience.
Frankly, I never dreamed that I would live long enough to see the American promise turned to a reality in the body politic in such fashion.
It's a great moment, and I think Barack Obama was right when he said, America, this is our moment.
It's not a black moment.
it's not a Democrat Party moment.
it's truly an American moment for this is what America has claimed to be.
Let me ask Afi.
What was your response when you - that night?
The same way that Reverend Lowery described his.
I went on Facebook to write on my niece's wall.
She's 22.
She lives in Chattanooga, Tennessee.
And what I was struck by was the fact that she said that she was happy her 91-year-old great grandmother, my grandmother, lived to see the moment.

And after I responded to that, I called my grandmother's sister, who is in her 80s, and we have been sharing this since Iowa, and we just talked about the span of her life and the span of my life, and how miraculous this is.
We've been using the word ""miraculous"" quite a bit.

Reverend Lowery, looking back through the civil rights struggle, is there an event, a singular moment, or a specific thing that you can point to that brought us to this day with a black man conceivably winning the White House?
Well, I think we have to go back to - oh, my God, we can go to so many places.
The first thing that came to mind was 1957, when Martin stood in Washington at a prayer pilgrimage and cried, give us the ballot!
We had not yet the right to vote in many, many states in this country.
And Martin saw the ballot as a means of unlocking doors that had been closed and locked against justice and liberty for generations to come.

Then I have to go, again, to the Voting Rights Act, which came as a result of that cry and the Selma to Montgomery Movement, which removed barriers and restrictions from voting, and not only permitted African-Americans to vote, but permitted African-Americans to run and to seek public office.
Those are two of the instances that come to mind, and I could, I could whip my memory box and come up with some more if I had to.
But those two come to mind at the beginning.
Afi, let me put this question to you.
Do you think that black people have been wrong about how whites see African-Americans?
Or do you think that that perception has changed, embodied by the nomination of Barack Obama?
No, I don't think black people have been wrong about how white see African-Americans.
I live in Ohio, and Barack didn't take Ohio.
We haven't been able to elect a black person to a statewide office in Ohio since I lived here, and I moved here in 1990.
However, I do think his victory gives us inspiration and shows us that the overcoming is possible.
I think we had been so beat down that we had forgotten that we have the power.
We can flex our muscles, and we have flexed our muscles in the past.
Joseph Lowery, Reverend Lowery can talk about that.
I think our people had lost hope, and I think this has given us hope in our power again.
If - Reverend Lowery, if Obama were to lose in November, how much would that change the euphoria that so many African-Americans are experiencing at the moment?
And would it signal, do you think, that things haven't really change all that much?
I'm not even going to think about it.

I think that we're on the road, and I think that American people, you know, when Martin cried and - on August 28th when they officially name Obama the Democratic nominee, it will be exactly 45 years since the March on Washington, when Martin cried, you know, don't judge us by the color of our skin.
Judge us by our character.
And I think that's what the American people have done.
American voters in these primaries and caucuses have felt it pull at their heartstrings.

They felt deep speaking onto deep, and they have responded without regard, without restriction of color and gender, for - as a matter of fact, I think we have to consider that as a mark of progress as well.
But I think that's going to catch on, and I think it's going to continue through November.

And I think we are going to see Barack Obama reap the benefit of people looking at the candidates through commitment, through an intellect, through character, and through the belief and faith in their determination to turn the page in this country's history.

Afi, to final that point, Reverend Lowery's point, how much of a difference do you think Obama being elected president would make to the everyday lives of not only African-Americans but white Americans as well?
I think it would be revolutionary.
I just want to say, though, that you don't get a revolution without pain.
And in this country ,you have to realize that white identity is built upon notions of supremacy.
I think it would be very, very traumatic to the established notion of white identity, because now, in order to admit that someone is your equal, you have to acknowledge you are not superior.
So I think on that issue or that point, we're going to see a seat change.
In terms of African-Americans, I think it could be revolutionary for us because we will really have no excuses.
It doesn't mean that racism doesn't exist, it doesn't mean it's not institutionalized, but we cannot say that it is more powerful than we are, or that our efforts cannot defeat it.
So, I think that it could be quite traumatic, quite painful and quite joyful at the same time.

Reverend Lowery , there has been talk for some time now, I know that you are aware of this, about whether there is still a need for a civil rights movement as we have known it because of the changed outlook on race by younger Americans.
Is Obama's nomination evidence of that?
That we don't need a civil right movement?
Not in the way that we have in the past.
Well, I'm glad you qualified it because the - we have not reach our goal.
Obama's nomination, nor his election, would mean the automatic elimination of all racial disparities and racial discrimination in this country.
It would've reached another level, another high mark, but we'll still have a long way to go.
And I think we always must remain vigilant.

We always must insist that that the standards and the barometers used to measure progress and to measure justice are - respect the commitment to move beyond race and gender and color and creed and et cetera.
There won't be - it's a new beginning.
There is no automatic end to racism and racial restrictions because of this nomination, nor even because of the election.
Yes, we will still need vigilance and determination to keep a nation honest.

Do you think that Barack Obama's involvement in politics, to the point that he has reached so far, has it - are there already signs that there is a coattail effect for others who would aspire to something as high as this?
Oh, I don't think there's any doubt but that he has had a sweeping effect across the country, and many candidates for office are now hoping that they will be swept into office.
And so do I, because it would be tragic if he ends up with a Congress that is, you know, that expresses antipathy toward his objectives and his ideals and his commitment.
So, I would hope that his coattail is wide.
I hope that he gets the kind of Congress that will support him and work him.
And I think the people's mandate will help in that and that will help influence Congress, but yes, we're going to have to continue to hope that his coattails are wide.
Final thing for you, Afi, is this.
Do you think that African-Americans, in particular, the electorate, we know that it has energized for the primary, but will it continue through the general, do you think?
The general election?
Yes.
Yes.
I definitely think so.
I think Americans in general are much more sophisticated about the political process.
I think African-Americans had been feeling disillusioned and disenfranchised.
I'm really hoping that African-Americans will turn the hope into work, and I am optimistic about that.
I'm optimistic about that.
My 88-year-old aunt is talking about taking people to the polls in Chicago.
(Soundbite of laughter)
She has to.
So, when I hear that, then I feel like, you know, the efforts are going to be there.
Folks are going to hit the street.
People understand that this is going to be a victory that will be very narrow and we're going to have to work to get it.
In 10 seconds, Reverend Lowery, is this the mountain top that Reverend King was talking about?
Well, it's supporting it.
It's at least another plateau.
And I don't think we're at the top yet, but we are climbing in the right direction, and with our faces turned toward the city of justice and the city of hope and the city of promise.

And I think Barack's spiritual presence has had such a positive impact on citizens, black and white, brown and red and yellow, and I hope it will continue and we will see this as a beginning of a new era in human relations.
